sections.title: SOURCES
sections.content_md:
The establishment of the **Delhi Sultanate** at the beginning of the 13th century marked a new phase in India's cultural development. The interaction between the Turks and the Indians led to a new composite culture, the **Indo-Islamic culture**, which was a fusion of the best elements of both, not purely Persian or entirely Indian.

This culture had two distinct growth phases:
1.  **The Sultanate phase:** Marked by the fusion of Indian traditions with Turkish culture.
2.  **The Mughal phase:** Marked the consolidation of this composite culture.

The main sources of information about this composite culture are as follows:

sections.title: Bijak
sections.content_md:
**Bijak** (the seed book) is the compilation of the verses of **Kabir**, a disciple of the Bhakti saint **Ramananda**. Born around AD 1398 to a Brahmin widow, he was abandoned and then rescued and raised by a Muslim weaver, **Neeru**, and his wife, **Neema**. Acquainted with Hindu and Muslim ideas, Kabir aimed to transform society by promoting peace and harmony.

Kabir was an oral poet whose works were written down by others. The **Bijak** is preserved by the **Kabirpanthis** (followers of Kabir) in Varanasi and Uttar Pradesh.

**Kabir's Teachings According to Bijak:**
*   **One God:** There is only one God, who may be worshipped under many names.
*   **Means of Salvation:** Devotion to God and good actions are the only paths to salvation.
*   **Purity:** One must be free from dishonesty, insincerity, and hypocrisy to reach God.
*   **Equality:** All men are equal before God; there are no caste distinctions or supremacy of the priestly class.
*   **Denunciation of Rituals:** He condemned idol worship, empty rituals, meaningless ceremonies, and pilgrimages.

Bijak presents Kabir's compositions in a simple style, urging listeners to abandon delusions and orthodox views for a direct experience of truth.

sections.title: Sakhi
sections.content_md: The **Sakhi** is composed in the **doha** or couplet form.

sections.title: Ramaini
sections.content_md: The **Ramaini** form is typically written in the **chaupai** metre and is based on a musical raga. It is descriptive and lengthy.

sections.title: Shabda
sections.content_md: The **Shabda** is the most metrically loose form. As a popular song form, it has been altered across different regions and singers.

sections.title: Guru Granth Sahib
sections.content_md:
The **Guru Granth Sahib** was compiled by the fifth Sikh Guru, **Guru Arjan Dev**. It included the hymns of **Guru Nanak Dev**, his four successors, and other religious preachers like **Baba Farid, Ravidas, and Kabir** in the **Adi Granth Sahib** in Amritsar. The tenth Guru, **Guru Gobind Singh**, later added the compositions of the ninth Guru, **Guru Teg Bahadur**, and the scripture was then called the **Guru Granth Sahib**.

The entire scripture is written in the **Gurmukhi script**. It is considered a **'Living Guru'** by Sikhs, a spiritual guide for all humanity.

**Guru Nanak's Teachings:**
*   Preached the unity of God and the unity of mankind.
*   Advocated devotion over ritualism.
*   Believed, "there is one God, His name is Eternal Truth, He is the maker of all things."
*   Emphasised devotion and the repetition of **Satnam** (God's name) combined with meditation as the only means to escape the cycle of birth and rebirth.
*   Believed personal devotion leads to salvation, regardless of caste, creed, or sect.
*   Advocated a middle path, combining spiritual life with householder duties.
*   Condemned idolatry, hypocrisy, and insincerity.

sections.title: Introductory section composed by Guru Nanak
sections.content_md: The Guru Granth Sahib is divided into two sections, the first being an introductory section composed by Guru Nanak.

sections.title: Compositions of Sikh gurus, followed by those of other saints and mystics, collected according to the chronology of ragas or musical settings
sections.content_md: The second section contains the compositions of Sikh gurus, followed by the works of other saints and mystics. These are organized according to the chronology of **ragas** or musical settings. The inclusion of a wide variety of saints, sages, and bards affirms the fundamental unity of all religions and mystic experiences.

sections.title: Ajmer Sharief
sections.content_md:
**Ajmer Sharief** is the holy shrine (dargah) of the Sufi saint **Khwajah Moinuddin Chishti**, located in Ajmer, Rajasthan. The saint came to India with Mahmud of Ghazni and made Ajmer his headquarters until his death in AD 1236. The site is revered by people of all faiths.

*   **Annual Festival:** A yearly carnival known as **Urs** is held for six days in the saint's honour.
*   **Key Attractions:** The main attraction is the mausoleum containing the tomb of the saint. The dargah complex includes many buildings and courtyards from the Mughal period.
*   **Gates:** The main gate is the **Nizam Gate**, followed by the **Shahjahani Gate** (built by Shah Jahan) and the **Buland Darwaza**.
*   **Degs (Cauldrons):** At the courtyard entrance are two large cauldrons for cooking food, one presented by Emperor Akbar and the other by Emperor Jahangir.
*   **The Tomb:** The tomb is made of white marble inlaid with precious stones. It is covered by a silver canopy (**chaparkhat**) inlaid with mother-of-pearl, presented by Emperor Jahangir.

sections.title: St. Francis Church (Kochi)
sections.content_md:
**St. Francis Church** in Fort Kochi, originally built in 1503, is the oldest European church in India.

*   **Vasco da Gama:** The Portuguese explorer died in Kochi in 1524 and was originally buried in this church. After fourteen years, his remains were moved to Lisbon, but his gravestone can still be seen here.
*   **Construction History:**
    *   After Vasco da Gama's arrival in 1498, the Portuguese built a fort at Kochi and a wooden church within it.
    *   In 1506, the Portuguese viceroy, **Francisco de Almeida**, received permission to rebuild the church in stone and masonry. This was likely done by Franciscan friars of the order of St. Francis of Assisi.
    *   The Dutch captured Kochi in 1663 and took control of the church.
    *   The British captured Kochi in 1795. In 1804, the Dutch handed the church to the Anglican sect, who are believed to have changed its name to St. Francis Church.

sections.title: St. Francis Assisi
sections.content_md:
**St. Francis of Assisi** was an Italian Roman Catholic priest and preacher, born in 1182 to a prosperous silk merchant. After experiencing a vision, he abandoned his ambitions of military glory and embarked on a preaching ministry.

He and his companions rebuilt the small church of the **Portiuncola** near Assisi, which became their base. He founded the **Order of Friars Minor**, a religious society that grew rapidly and sent missions to other countries.

Francis died on October 3, 1226, and was declared a saint by Pope Gregory IX on July 16, 1228. Many churches across India have been dedicated to him.

sections.title: Factors Responsible for the Growth of Composite Culture
sections.content_md:
*   **Patronage:** The immense wealth and unlimited power of the Mughal emperors enabled them to patronize fine arts, literature, and the construction of palaces, forts, and monuments.
*   **Peace and Stability:** The long period of peace and settled conditions in northern India created a conducive environment for undertaking extensive works of art.
*   **Aesthetic Sense:** The Mughal Emperors possessed a great sense of beauty and art, seeking to express it through various visual forms.
*   **Cultural Heritage:** The glorious and rich cultural heritage of both the Mughals and the Indians created a unique atmosphere for the brilliant output of letters and fine arts.

sections.title: Impact of Composite Culture
sections.content_md: The Indo-Islamic culture had a significant impact on all aspects of life, including culture, art, architecture, and literature.

sections.title: The dress, manners, social amenities and festivals which the Mughals introduced in India, were accepted by the people in India
sections.content_md: The dress, manners, social amenities and festivals introduced by the Mughals were widely accepted by the people of India, reflecting the cultural fusion.

sections.title: The trend towards fusion of two cultures is best seen in the field of music.
sections.content_md: The fusion of cultures is most evident in music. The Turks introduced new musical instruments like the **rabab** and **sarangi**, as well as new musical modes. **Amir Khusrau**, who was given the title of **nayak**, introduced many Perso-Arabic ragas.

sections.title: During the reign of Akbar, there was a fusion of Persian and Indian style of painting.
sections.content_md: Under Akbar, Persian and Indian painting styles merged. Painting was organized in imperial establishments (**karkhanas**). Painters illustrated Persian fables, the **Mahabharata**, and the **Akbarnama**. These paintings incorporated Indian themes and colours like peacock blue and Indian red. The most notable work from this period is the **Dastan-i-Amir Hamza** (or Hamzanama), a manuscript with nearly 1200 paintings.

sections.title: In the field of architecture, the Indian and Islamic systems of art were mingled to give rise to a new type of Indo-Islamic architecture.
sections.content_md:
A new **Indo-Islamic architecture** emerged from the fusion of Indian and Islamic art systems. Its significant features were:
*   **Characteristics:** Islamic architecture introduced spaciousness, massiveness, majesty, and width to Indian architecture.
*   **Decoration:** The Turks avoided depicting human and animal figures, instead using geometrical and floral designs combined with inscriptions of Quranic verses. They also borrowed Indian motifs like the **swastika, bell, and lotus**. For instance, the lotus is a decorative device in the buildings of Firoz Tughlaq.
*   **Influence on Temples:** Mughal traditions influenced the architecture of temples and palaces. Many temples in Vrindavan adopted the Mughal style. The **Golden Temple** at Amritsar was built on the arch and dome principle of Islamic architecture and incorporated Mughal features.

sections.title: Language and literature also saw the influence of the two traditions.
sections.content_md:
The language of administration under the Mughal rulers was **Persian**, which eventually became the language of the upper classes as well.

The greatest linguistic synthesis was the development of **Urdu**, a mixture of Persian, Arabic, Hindi, and other regional languages. Originally known as **'Zaban-e-Hindvi'**, it became popular during the Mughal rule and served as a means of spreading information and Islamic thought. Many Sanskrit books were also translated into Persian and Urdu.

sections.title: SUFISM AND BHAKTI MOVEMENT
sections.content_md:
The spirit of tolerance and mutual influence in Indo-Islamic culture led to two liberal religious reform movements: the **Sufi** and **Bhakti** movements.

Sufi and Bhakti saints emphasized the essential unity of Islam and Hinduism, promoting a religion based on love and devotion rather than rituals. This created an atmosphere where liberal sentiments grew and religious narrowness was shunned, playing an important role in fostering Indo-Islamic culture.

sections.title: BHAKTI MOVEMENT
sections.content_md:
The Bhakti movement originated as a reaction against caste division and ritualism in India. It was started by the **Vaishnava** and **Saiva** saints of the south. In the 11th and 12th centuries, Tamil Vaishnava saints (**Alvars**) and Saivite saints (**Nayanars**) preached 'personal devotion to God as a means to reach God.' These ideas spread to North India and became popular between the 11th and 15th centuries.

'**Bhakti**' means devotion to God and its philosophical roots are in the revival led by Shankaracharya. Prominent followers of the Bhakti cult included **Ramanujacharya, Madhavacharya, Ramananda, Kabir, Nanak, Namdev, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu,** and **Mirabai**.

sections.title: Doctrines of Bhakti Cult
sections.content_md:
1.  **One God:** God is one and must be worshipped with love and devotion.
2.  **Path to Salvation:** Salvation can be found by following the path of true devotion (Bhakti), not through blind faith or empty ceremonies.
3.  **Equality:** All are equal before God. A person's dignity depends on their actions, not their birth. Universal brotherhood is a reality.
4.  **The Guru:** An enlightened teacher (Guru) is indispensable for realizing God.
5.  **Rejection of Rituals:** Religious rites and ceremonies are devoid of substance. Man can reach God only through absolute surrender.
6.  **Social Harmony:** One must avoid caste distinctions and class-hatred.

sections.title: IMPACT OF BHAKTI MOVEMENT
sections.content_md:
The Bhakti Movement, like Sufism, brought profound changes to the religious and social outlook of people.
1.  **Universal Brotherhood:** Bhakti saints preached universal brotherhood and emphasized the equality of all men.
2.  **Vernacular Languages:** They preached in the language of the people, leading to the popularization of languages like Hindi, Bhojpuri, Maithili, and Oriya. Important literary works from this period include the **Ramcharit Manas** by Tulsidas, the Gurmukhi literature of the Sikh Gurus, and the Vaishnava literature in Bengal.
3.  **Social Reforms:** The teachings of saints like Kabir, Guru Nanak, and Ravidas helped reform Indian society. They promoted a new social order based on equality, denounced caste distinctions, exposed the futility of empty rituals, and ended the domination of priests.

sections.title: Mirabai
sections.content_md:
**Mirabai** was a Rajasthani princess of Mewar who lived during the time of the Mughal ruler Akbar. The only daughter of a Rajput noble, she was married to **Bhoja Raj**, the heir apparent of Rana Sanga of Mewar. She renounced the world to become a devotee of Lord Krishna.

Her devotional songs (**bhajans**) made her popular and are sung even today. She mixed with ordinary people, showing them through her own example how to surrender to Lord Krishna. Her brilliant poetry is known as **Padavali**, which portrays a deep personal association with Lord Krishna.

sections.title: Sant Jnaneswar
sections.content_md:
**Sant Jnaneswar** (or Dnyaneshwar) was a 13th-century saint, poet, and philosopher from Maharashtra. He learned philosophy and kundalini yoga from his elder brother, **Nivrittinatha**.

*   **Major Works:** At the age of 15, he delivered a nine-thousand-verse commentary on the Bhagvad Gita called the **Jnaneswari** (also known as **Bhavartha Dipika**). He also wrote **Amritanubhava**, a treatise on his spiritual experiences.
*   **Beliefs and Movement:** He regarded **bhakti** (devotion) as the means to liberation. Influenced by the saint Namdev, he joined the **Varkari movement** and became its leader. The movement's main practice is remembering God at all times and living a simple, virtuous life while helping others.
*   **Legacy:** His teachings inspired great devotion, and his followers walk hundreds of kilometres to Pandharpur to worship Lord Vitthal. His famous works, known as **Abhangas**, graphically describe his visits to holy places. In 1296, he took **samadhi** (a state of meditative consciousness) at Alandi, where his shrine is a highly revered place for the Varkari sect.

sections.title: SUFISM
sections.content_md:
The word '**Sufi**' is believed to come from the Arabic word **Suf** (meaning wool), as the mystics wore coarse woollen garments. Some scholars trace it to **'safa'** (meaning purity). Sufis came to India with the Turkish rulers and started a movement preaching religious tolerance, brotherhood, and the oneness of God.

The Sufi saints were organized into 12 orders or **silsilas** (literally meaning a chain, signifying the link between master and disciple). The leader of an order was the **pir**, and his followers were **murids**. A successor, called a **wali**, was nominated by the pir. Each order had a **Khanqah**, or hermitage. The Sufi saints who settled in India primarily belonged to the **Chishti** and **Suhrawardi** orders.

sections.title: Doctrines of Sufism
sections.content_md:
1.  **Unity of Religions:** Belief in the fundamental unity of all religions.
2.  **Personal Devotion:** One can reach God through personal devotion, not through empty rituals.
3.  **Union with God:** The individual soul is a manifestation of the supreme God and will ultimately merge with it.
4.  **Equality and Brotherhood:** All human beings are equal, irrespective of caste, colour, creed, and religion.
5.  **Inner Purity:** Inner purity and self-discipline are essential for gaining knowledge of God.

sections.title: Impact of Sufism
sections.content_md:
1.  **Hindu-Muslim Unity:** It fostered feelings of unity between Hindus and Muslims.
2.  **Support for Bhakti Movement:** Many Sufi principles were similar to those of the Bhakti cult, which helped increase the popularity of the Bhakti Movement.
3.  **Tolerance:** Sufism played a great role in promoting feelings of tolerance among rulers.
4.  **Mutual Respect:** People of different religions began to understand and appreciate each other's faith.
5.  **Literary Influence:** Sufism influenced poets of the period, such as **Amir Khusro** and **Malik Muhammed Jayasi**, who composed poems in Persian and Hindi praising Sufi principles.

sections.title: Hazrat Nizamuddin
sections.content_md:
**Hazrat Nizamuddin** was a famous Sufi saint of the **Chishti order** who believed in drawing close to God through renunciation of the world and service to humanity. He was born in Badayun, Uttar Pradesh. At the age of twenty, he became a disciple of the Sufi saint **Baba Farid** in Ajodhan (present-day Pakistan). Baba Farid later made him his successor.

He built his **Khanqah** (hospice) in Delhi, which became a centre for spiritual education and feeding people from all walks of life. Like his predecessors, he stressed love as a means of realizing God, believing that love of God implied love of humanity.

**His key beliefs included:**
*   Renunciation and complete trust in God.
*   The unity of mankind and shunning distinctions based on social, economic, or religious status.
*   Helping the needy, feeding the hungry, and being sympathetic to the oppressed.
*   Strong disapproval of mixing with Sultans, princes, and nobles.
*   An uncompromising attitude towards all forms of political and social oppression.

His shrine, the **Nizamuddin Dargah**, is located in Delhi and was built in 1562. It is visited by people of all faiths. It becomes a place for special congregation during the **urs** (death anniversary) of Hazrat Nizamuddin and **Amir Khusro**, who is also buried there.

sections.title: INFLUENCE OF CHRISTIANITY
sections.content_md: The arrival of **Vasco da Gama** in Calicut in 1498 is a landmark in the history of Christianity in India. With the arrival of the Portuguese, Roman Catholic Missions to India became more organised, initially confined to coastal areas like Goa, Kochi, and Tuticorin. **St. Francis Xavier**, who arrived in 1542, was the first Jesuit missionary in India and played a significant role in spreading Christianity.

sections.title: St. Francis Xavier
sections.content_md:
**St. Francis Xavier** was born on April 7, 1506, in Spain. He became a priest in 1537 and landed in Goa in 1542 on his missionary journey. For the first five months, he preached and attended to the sick in hospitals. He would walk the streets ringing a bell to invite children to church, where he would explain the beliefs of Christianity.

By 1548, he had established several missions and sent other Jesuit missionaries to these centres. He worked relentlessly in India for ten years. He died on December 2, 1552, during a voyage to China. His mortal remains were brought back to Goa the following year; it was said his body was as fresh as on the day of his burial. The body of St. Francis Xavier is still enshrined in the **Basilica of Bom Jesus** in Goa.

sections.title: IMPACT OF CHRISTIAN MISSIONARIES
sections.content_md:
Christian missionaries spread Christianity and also played a significant role in promoting language, literature, and art.

*   **Language and Literature:**
    *   Missionaries produced grammars and dictionaries of Indian languages. **St. Francis Xavier** learned the language of Malabar and created a grammar manual and vocabulary.
    *   The English Jesuit, **Thomas Stephens**, wrote an epic in Konkani and a grammar book. Another missionary, **Diogo Ribeiro**, wrote a grammar book and booklets on Christian doctrines.

*   **Music and Arts:**
    *   They introduced Western music, dance, and instrumental music in Church schools. Many churches had music schools where hymns were sung, accompanied by organs and other instruments.
    *   The Missionaries and the Church were patrons of painting, carving, and sculpture, mostly with religious themes. These paintings influenced Mughal art; records show that **Akbar** and **Jahangir** were interested in Christian art. Akbar possessed a painting of Jesus and the Blessed Virgin, and Jahangir had an album of miniatures with Christian themes.

*   **Architecture:**
    *   The Portuguese Church provided the earliest introduction of European architectural ideas to India, including the long, two-storeyed house with a high-pitched roof, balconies, verandas, multiple windows, and elaborately carved walls.

*   **Cultural Interpretation:**
    *   Through their popular letters from the mission field, the Missionaries became the best interpreters of India to the Western world.
